coredata.dc:title: Fluctuation and correlation of electrons in molecular systems
coredata.dc:creator: Bader, R.F.W.
Stephens, M.E.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
It is shown that the fluctuation in the electron population of a region of real space (or loge) provides a measure of the extent of the correlative interactions between the motions of the electrons in that space. The vanishing of the fluctuation requires that the “correlation hole” for each particle in the loge be totally contained within the boundaries of the loge.

In the present approach for example, we have found that the more diffuse valence density of A 2~r excited state of BeH cannot be partitioned by the minimization of A(N, oe2) into two loges, as is the case for the ground state. Instead, A(N, oe2) was minimized only when all three electrons were included in the same loge, implying that the Fermi hole for any one of the electrons could not be well localized in a region of space separate from that of the others.
